author: The Telegraph
title: Top airport restaurants: a dinner worth flying for
text: Setting aside the jokes about airport food, the truth is that these days it’s fairly easy to dine well on planes. Of course, there are varying levels of luxury, but from full English breakfasts to tiger prawns and quinoa, it’s hard to go wrong if you’re flying in business class . British Airways customers can enjoy china table service and an award-winning wine list. And if you think that sounds tasty, those flying first can choose from a range of soufflés and a cheese board with tasting notes. Even so, there are real treats to be had back on the ground, all over the world. If you’re lucky enough to be flying for business, see if you can get away with putting some of these delectable dining experiences on expenses while you’re in transit. Pappadeaux Houston-Hobby Airport How about something with a bit of zing to beat the jet lag? Local legends the Pappas brothers deliver big on Cajun and Creole-inspired flavours – including alligator – to ensure you know where you are, even if you have no idea what time it is. The Salt Lick Bar-B-Que Austin-Bergstrom Airport Before leaving Texas it makes sense to hit the grill, and this place is famous for it. Just don’t eat it in the same outfit you’re wearing to your next meeting – real BBQ can get real messy. Airbräu Brauhaus Munich Airport Europe's only airport restaurant to boast its own on-site brewery, this Bavarian brewhouse has everything you’d expect from the famed region’s beer and meat-heavy menus in generous portions. Prost! Meat feast: a sandwich at the Salt Lick Bar-B-Que can get pretty messy Altitude Geneva Airport Classic French food? Check. View of the runway? Check. If you’re the sort of traveller who knows their morels from their mallard, this is the one for you. Asian Kitchen by Susur Lee Toronto Pearson International Airport Created by Canada’s winner of Iron Chef – the American equivalent to Masterchef – this fine dining fusion restaurant brings French and Chinese influences together to stunning effect. Dani Garcia DeliBar Málaga-Costa del Sol Airport This modern tapas bar serves up some unusual treats in the classic format – small, brilliant bites served on display for your choice. Sit back and tuck in, but remember to keep an eye on the departures board. Hung's Delicacies Hong Kong International Airport This baby brother to the Michelin-starred Hung's Delicacies in North Point delivers Chiu Chow food. Deep, hearty stocks fortify meats ranging from pork to goose, with some more unusual choices (for western palates) including duck’s tongue. Hearty stocks: food at Hung's Delicacies in Hong Kong ranges from goose to pork The Perfectionists' Café Heathrow Airport T2 At Terminal 2 Heston Blumenthal has turned his attention to rapid-fire British classics, delivering the usual quirky twists we’ve come to expect from him without any sacrifice in quality. Porta Gaig Barcelona-El Prat Airport Serving both tapas and small plates as well as heartier Catalan fare, this restaurant is weekdays-only. If you’re only passing through the city, grab your chance to discover why Carles Gaig is one of the city’s most celebrated chefs. Top Air Stuttgart Airport This award-winning European masterpiece caters to those travellers who simply cannot start their journey without an amuse-bouche. For those with a slightly longer changeover, there's a seven-course tasting menu to tuck into. Raising the bar: Gordon Ramsay's restaurant is perfect for dining on the go Plane Food Heathrow Airport (T5) Gordon Ramsay delivers all the quality you’d expect at this luxurious Terminal 5 outpost, and offers packed options for those dining on the go. It beats a sandwich. Brasserie Flo Charles de Gaulle Airport Classic brasserie fare served with classic Gallic flair. This established Parisian restaurant is the perfect place to put away a chateaubriand while reflecting on a well-executed business deal. Le Sommelier Copenhagen Airport Great food, a well-stocked wine cellar and all the ambience of a much-loved city eatery. This is where expense accounts like to travel. When it’s this good, why bother meeting outside the airport at all? • Find out more about how to receive business travel rewards by visiting British Airways On Business
